thread.title: Nevada's legal brothels are the state's not-so-secret vice
thread.title_full: Nevada's legal brothels are the state's not-so-secret vice

title: Nevada's legal brothels are the state's not-so-secret vice
text:
Nevada's legal brothels are the state's not-so-secret vice 4:32 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015 | Filed in: Celebrity news Comments 0 ï»¿ 
When former NBA player and reality-TV star Lamar Odom was found unconscious in Nevada this week, the hardest part of the story for some people to wrap their heads around was this: He was in a brothel. A legal brothel. 
Call it Nevada's not-so-secret vice: It is the only state with legal prostitution. It has been selling sex with the blessing of the law for years, even if legislators aren't exactly thrilled about it. FILE - In this July 31, 2009, file photo, Los Angeles Lakers' Lamar Odom speaks to the media during a news conference after the Lakers signed Odom to a multi-year NBA basketball contract, in El Segundo, Calif. Odom spent most of his 14-year NBA career in Los Angeles with the Lakers and Clippers, becoming a fan favorite before he sought even more fame with the Kardashians. Odom, who was embraced by teammates and television fans alike for his Everyman approach to fame, was found face-down and alone Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, after spending four days at the Love Ranch, a legal Nevada brothel. (AP Photo/Jeff Lewis, File) 
While the law of supply and demand would suggest that Nevada's one-of-a-kind brothels are doing great, the truth is they are struggling to remain relevant. In a world in which sex is only a smartphone app away, the number of legal bordellos has fallen, and those that remain are trying to reinvent themselves.
